conclusion: Introduction to the problem and mention of motional EMF due to electromagnetic induction.
The conductor rod ab has a length of 4L, rotates around point O, and the distance between a and O is negligible.
The rod rotates at a constant angular velocity ω about an axis perpendicular to the paper.
There is a uniform magnetic field with magnetic induction intensity B, assumed to be perpendicular to the plane of rotation.
Need to find the potential difference U_ab between points a and b.
The image shows a rod labeled ab, with a near O, and the rod extending to point b.
Since the rod is moving in a magnetic field, it induces an EMF due to the Lorentz force on charges in the conductor.
The EMF induced in a conductor moving in a magnetic field is given by the motional EMF formula.
The potential difference U_ab will be equal to the induced EMF between points a and b.
Place point O at the origin in the xy-plane, with the rod along the x-axis.
The rod rotates around an axis through O, perpendicular to the paper, with angular velocity ω in the +z-direction.
The magnetic field B is uniform and perpendicular to the plane of rotation, B = B z-hat.
For a point at distance r from O, the linear velocity due to rotation is v = ωr.
At r = 0 (point a), v = 0; at r = 4L (point b), v = 4ωL.
Compute the cross product v x B = -ωrB x-hat.
Compute the dot product (v x B) · dl = -ωrB dr.
The induced EMF is the integral from a to b: E = -ωB ∫ r dr from 0 to 4L.
Calculate the integral to find E = -8ωBL^2.
The magnitude of the EMF is |E| = 8ωBL^2.
The negative EMF indicates the electric field is from b to a, so b is at a higher potential.
The potential difference U_ab = V_b - V_a = |E| = 8ωBL^2.
